headline.main: Getting Physical as Part of the Daily Routine

docs.abstract: Interview with Loretta A DiPietro, asst fellow at John B Pierce Laboratory, who contributed section on physical activity and obesity to Surgeon General's report released in July; she comments on adopting more healthful life style; her photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: DRIVE-THROUGH windows, remote controls and computers may make life simpler, but they are also making Americans more sedentary. Loretta A. DiPietro considers this a tragedy, a major cause of obesity and disease. Dr. DiPietro, an assistant fellow at the John B. Pierce Laboratory in New Haven and an assistant professor of epidemiology and public health at the Yale School of Medicine, contributed a section on physical activity and obesity to the Surgeon General's report released in July.

headline.main: Why America's Ever-Fatter Kids Don't Go to Gym

docs.abstract: Health experts tracking weight gain among America's increasingly sedentary children are upset over trend toward reduced spending on physical education in schools; cuts dovetail with evolving, less competitive approach to gym class; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FEW memories of coming of age have the enduring sting of gym class: the sinking feeling of being the last player picked for a team, the valiant struggle to muster a chin-up or the failure to clamber even a few inches toward the ceiling up a bristly, seemingly endless rope. Given such experiences, it's not surprising that many gym-class alumni, now parents and educators, have been willing to tolerate cuts in physical education to pay for traditionally more pressing priorities like computer instruction. Likewise, it's a safe bet that their kids returning to school next week aren't too upset about the cuts either. But to health experts tracking the ballooning of America's increasingly sedentary children, the trend is a dangerous one.
